questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "QUALIFIER LEVEL : ENGLISH I (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" MANDATORILY YOU HAVE TO ATTEND ALL THE SECTIONS
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "QUALIFIER LEVEL : ENGLISH I (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" MANDATORILY YOU HAVE TO ATTEND ALL THE SECTIONS

questions.question_text_1:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions.
 When I first visited Gandhi in 1942 at his ashram in Sevagram, in central India, he said, “I will tell you how it happened that I decided to urge the departure of the British. It was in 1917.”   He had gone to the December 1916 annual convention of the Indian National Congress party in Lucknow. There were 2,301 delegates and many visitors. "During the proceedings," Gandhi recounted, “a peasant came up to me looking like any other peasant in India, poor and emaciated, and said, ‘I am Rajkumar Shukla. I am from Champaran, and I want you to come to my district’!’’ Gandhi had never heard of the place. It was in the foothills of the towering Himalayas, near the kingdom of Nepal.   Under an ancient arrangement, the Champaran peasants were sharecroppers. Rajkumar Shukla was one of them. He was illiterate but resolute. He had come to the Congress session to complain about the injustice of the landlord system in Bihar, and somebody had probably said, “Speak to Gandhi.”   Gandhi told Shukla he had an appointment in Cawnpore and was also committed to go to other parts of India. Shukla accompanied him everywhere. Then Gandhi returned to his ashram near Ahmedabad. Shukla followed him to the ashram. For weeks he never left Gandhi’s side.   “Fix a date,” he begged.   Impressed by the sharecropper’s tenacity and story Gandhi said, ‘‘I have to be in Calcutta on such-and-such a date. Come and meet me and take me from there.” Months passed. Shukla was sitting on his haunches at the appointed spot in Calcutta when Gandhi arrived; he waited till Gandhi was free. Then the two of them boarded a train for the city of Patna in Bihar. There Shukla led him to the house of a lawyer named Rajendra Prasad who later became President of the Congress party and of India. Rajendra Prasad was out of town, but the servants knew Shukla as a poor yeoman who pestered their master to help the indigo sharecroppers. So they let him stay on the grounds with his companion, Gandhi, whom they took to be another peasant. But Gandhi was not permitted to draw water from the well lest some drops from his bucket pollute the entire source; how did they know that he was not an untouchable?  Gandhi decided to go first to Muzzafarpur, which was en route to Champaran, to obtain more complete information about conditions than Shukla was capable of imparting. He accordingly sent a telegram to Professor J.B. Kripalani, of the Arts College in Muzzafarpur, whom he had seen at Tagore’s Shantiniketan school. The train arrived at midnight, 15 April 1917. Kripalani was waiting at the station with a large body of students. Gandhi stayed there for two days in the home of Professor Malkani, a teacher in a government school.   - Indigo - Louis Fischer
question_texts:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions.
 When I first visited Gandhi in 1942 at his ashram in Sevagram, in central India, he said, “I will tell you how it happened that I decided to urge the departure of the British. It was in 1917.”   He had gone to the December 1916 annual convention of the Indian National Congress party in Lucknow. There were 2,301 delegates and many visitors. "During the proceedings," Gandhi recounted, “a peasant came up to me looking like any other peasant in India, poor and emaciated, and said, ‘I am Rajkumar Shukla. I am from Champaran, and I want you to come to my district’!’’ Gandhi had never heard of the place. It was in the foothills of the towering Himalayas, near the kingdom of Nepal.   Under an ancient arrangement, the Champaran peasants were sharecroppers. Rajkumar Shukla was one of them. He was illiterate but resolute. He had come to the Congress session to complain about the injustice of the landlord system in Bihar, and somebody had probably said, “Speak to Gandhi.”   Gandhi told Shukla he had an appointment in Cawnpore and was also committed to go to other parts of India. Shukla accompanied him everywhere. Then Gandhi returned to his ashram near Ahmedabad. Shukla followed him to the ashram. For weeks he never left Gandhi’s side.   “Fix a date,” he begged.   Impressed by the sharecropper’s tenacity and story Gandhi said, ‘‘I have to be in Calcutta on such-and-such a date. Come and meet me and take me from there.” Months passed. Shukla was sitting on his haunches at the appointed spot in Calcutta when Gandhi arrived; he waited till Gandhi was free. Then the two of them boarded a train for the city of Patna in Bihar. There Shukla led him to the house of a lawyer named Rajendra Prasad who later became President of the Congress party and of India. Rajendra Prasad was out of town, but the servants knew Shukla as a poor yeoman who pestered their master to help the indigo sharecroppers. So they let him stay on the grounds with his companion, Gandhi, whom they took to be another peasant. But Gandhi was not permitted to draw water from the well lest some drops from his bucket pollute the entire source; how did they know that he was not an untouchable?  Gandhi decided to go first to Muzzafarpur, which was en route to Champaran, to obtain more complete information about conditions than Shukla was capable of imparting. He accordingly sent a telegram to Professor J.B. Kripalani, of the Arts College in Muzzafarpur, whom he had seen at Tagore’s Shantiniketan school. The train arrived at midnight, 15 April 1917. Kripalani was waiting at the station with a large body of students. Gandhi stayed there for two days in the home of Professor Malkani, a teacher in a government school.   - Indigo - Louis Fischer

questions.question_text_1: What is the meaning of ‘yeoman’ ?
question_texts: What is the meaning of ‘yeoman’ ?

options.option_text: A farmer who owned and worked on his own land
A person who is the owner of a house
A person who lends money as a business
A person who fits and repairs the pipes

Shukla accompanied him everywhere. Then Gandhi returned to his ashram near Ahmedabad. Shukla followed him to the ashram. For weeks he never left Gandhi’s side.   “Fix a date,” he begged.   Impressed by the sharecropper’s tenacity and story Gandhi said, ‘‘I have to be in Calcutta on such-and-such a date. Come and meet me and take me from there.” Months passed. Shukla was sitting on his haunches at the appointed spot in Calcutta when Gandhi arrived; he waited till Gandhi was free. Then the two of them boarded a train for the city of Patna in Bihar. There Shukla led him to the house of a lawyer named Rajendra Prasad who later became President of the Congress party and of India. Rajendra Prasad was out of town, but the servants knew Shukla as a poor yeoman who pestered their master to help the indigo sharecroppers. So they let him stay on the grounds with his companion, Gandhi, whom they took to be another peasant. But Gandhi was not permitted to draw water from the well lest some drops from his bucket pollute the entire source; how did they know that he was not an untouchable?  Gandhi decided to go first to Muzzafarpur, which was en route to Champaran, to obtain more complete information about conditions than Shukla was capable of imparting. He accordingly sent a telegram to Professor J.B. Kripalani, of the Arts College in Muzzafarpur, whom he had seen at Tagore’s Shantiniketan school. The train arrived at midnight, 15 April 1917. Kripalani was waiting at the station with a large body of students. Gandhi stayed there for two days in the home of Professor Malkani, a teacher in a government school.   - Indigo - Louis Fischer
question_texts:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions.
 When I first visited Gandhi in 1942 at his ashram in Sevagram, in central India, he said, “I will tell you how it happened that I decided to urge the departure of the British. It was in 1917.”   He had gone to the December 1916 annual convention of the Indian National Congress party in Lucknow. There were 2,301 delegates and many visitors. "During the proceedings," Gandhi recounted, “a peasant came up to me looking like any other peasant in India, poor and emaciated, and said, ‘I am Rajkumar Shukla. I am from Champaran, and I want you to come to my district’!’’ Gandhi had never heard of the place. It was in the foothills of the towering Himalayas, near the kingdom of Nepal.   Under an ancient arrangement, the Champaran peasants were sharecroppers. Rajkumar Shukla was one of them. He was illiterate but resolute. He had come to the Congress session to complain about the injustice of the landlord system in Bihar, and somebody had probably said, “Speak to Gandhi.”   Gandhi told Shukla he had an appointment in Cawnpore and was also committed to go to other parts of India. Shukla accompanied him everywhere. Then Gandhi returned to his ashram near Ahmedabad. Shukla followed him to the ashram. For weeks he never left Gandhi’s side.   “Fix a date,” he begged.   Impressed by the sharecropper’s tenacity and story Gandhi said, ‘‘I have to be in Calcutta on such-and-such a date. Come and meet me and take me from there.” Months passed. Shukla was sitting on his haunches at the appointed spot in Calcutta when Gandhi arrived; he waited till Gandhi was free. Then the two of them boarded a train for the city of Patna in Bihar. There Shukla led him to the house of a lawyer named Rajendra Prasad who later became President of the Congress party and of India. Rajendra Prasad was out of town, but the servants knew Shukla as a poor yeoman who pestered their master to help the indigo sharecroppers. So they let him stay on the grounds with his companion, Gandhi, whom they took to be another peasant. But Gandhi was not permitted to draw water from the well lest some drops from his bucket pollute the entire source; how did they know that he was not an untouchable?  Gandhi decided to go first to Muzzafarpur, which was en route to Champaran, to obtain more complete information about conditions than Shukla was capable of imparting. He accordingly sent a telegram to Professor J.B. Kripalani, of the Arts College in Muzzafarpur, whom he had seen at Tagore’s Shantiniketan school. The train arrived at midnight, 15 April 1917. Kripalani was waiting at the station with a large body of students. Gandhi stayed there for two days in the home of Professor Malkani, a teacher in a government school.   - Indigo - Louis Fischer

questions.question_text_1:
Read the following telephonic conversation and fill in the blanks with appropriate responses and answer the given subquestions:
 Sister: Hi bro, how are you doing?  Brother: Hey sis, (i)_____________________. How about you?  Sister: (ii)_________________. How is your preparation for exams going on?  Brother: Good, but I am really scared for my exams.  Sister:(iii)_______________  Brother: Because I think I am still lacking somewhere.  Sister: Don’t worry dear. You still have a month. You will do a better job!  Brother: (iv)_______________________. But I think I need more guidance.  Sister: For that, you can take coaching from the best institute which will help and guide you.  Brother: Yeah, this seems like the perfect idea. (v)______________________ Sister: There is a good coaching institute. It is called Genius Plus. Try to contact them.  Brother: Thank you, I will contact them immediately.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

The exam covers a range of topics in English language proficiency, including reading comprehension, vocabulary, grammar, pronunciation, and listening skills. Below is a detailed summary of the core topics and concepts:

#### Reading Comprehension
- **Understanding Passages**: Ability to read and understand detailed passages, including identifying main ideas, supporting details, and inferring meanings.
- **Vocabulary in Context**: Understanding the meaning of words based on the context in which they are used.

#### Vocabulary
- **Antonyms and Synonyms**: Knowledge of antonyms (e.g., tenacity vs. timidity) and synonyms.
- **Word Meanings**: Understanding specific word meanings (e.g., yeoman, lofty).
- **Word Collocation**: Matching words with their commonly associated words (e.g., sports equipment, library card).

#### Grammar
- **Parts of Speech**: Identifying nouns, pronouns, adjectives, adverbs, and verbs.
- **Pronouns**: Correct usage of pronouns (e.g., yours, yours).
- **Articles**: Proper use of articles (a, an, the) in sentences.
- **Prepositions**: Correct usage of prepositions (e.g., in, on, at).
- **Conjunctions**: Understanding and using conjunctions correctly (e.g., as if).

#### Pronunciation and Phonetics
- **Phonetic Sounds**: Identifying specific phonetic sounds in words (e.g., "aa" sound in "hard").
- **Diphthongs**: Recognizing words with and without diphthongs.
- **Semi-Vowels**: Identifying semi-vowels in word transitions (e.g., /w/ in "go out").

#### Listening Skills
- **Audio Comprehension**: Ability to listen to audio samples and identify specific words or phrases.

#### Phrasal Verbs and Idioms
- **Phrasal Verbs**: Understanding the meaning of phrasal verbs (e.g., lay off, break the ice).
- **Idioms**: Knowledge of common idioms and their meanings (e.g., get out of hand).

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[English Language Proficiency] --> B[Reading Comprehension]
    A --> C[Vocabulary]
    A --> D[Grammar]
    A --> E[Pronunciation and Phonetics]
    A --> F[Listening Skills]
    A --> G[Phrasal Verbs and Idioms]

    B --> B1[Understanding Passages]
    B --> B2[Vocabulary in Context]

    C --> C1[Antonyms and Synonyms]
    C --> C2[Word Meanings]
    C --> C3[Word Collocation]

    D --> D1[Parts of Speech]
    D --> D2[Pronouns]
    D --> D3[Articles]
    D --> D4[Prepositions]
    D --> D5[Conjunctions]

    E --> E1[Phonetic Sounds]
    E --> E2[Diphthongs]
    E --> E3[Semi-Vowels]

    F --> F1[Audio Comprehension]

    G --> G1[Phrasal Verbs]
    G --> G2[Idioms]
```

This knowledge graph visually maps the relationships between the core topics covered in the exam, providing a clear and easy-to-understand format for study and review.
